sections.title: 1. Symmetry Elements & Operations
sections.content: Symmetry analysis provides a rigorous way to describe the shape of molecules. A **symmetry operation** is an action that leaves the molecule apparently unchanged. Each operation is associated with a **symmetry element** (point, line, or plane).

visuals.note: Water has C2v symmetry: E, C2, and two mirror planes.

sections.title: 2. Proper Rotation (Cn)
sections.content:
A rotation by $360^\circ/n$ about an axis. The highest 'n' is the principal axis.

Example: **Ammonia (NH3)** has a $C_3$ axis ($120^\circ$ rotation).

sections.title: 3. Mirror Planes (σ)
sections.content:
Reflection through a plane.
- $\sigma_v$ (vertical): Contains the principal axis.
- $\sigma_h$ (horizontal): Perpendicular to the principal axis.

Example: **Benzene** has both $\sigma_v$ and a unique $\sigma_h$ plane.

visuals.note: Benzene (D6h) has a horizontal plane slicing the ring.

sections.title: 4. Improper Rotation (Sn) - Deep Dive
sections.content:
The **Improper Rotation ($S_n$)** is often the hardest to visualize. It consists of two steps performed in sequence:
1. **Rotation** by $360^\circ/n$ ($C_n$)
2. **Reflection** ($\sigma_h$) perpendicular to that axis.

Neither step needs to be a valid symmetry operation on its own, but the *combination* must be.

**Key Rule:** A molecule with *any* $S_n$ axis (including $S_1=\sigma$ and $S_2=i$) is **achiral**.

visuals.note: Methane has 3 S4 axes. Rotate 90° bisecting H-C-H, then reflect.
Staggered Ferrocene has an S10 axis!

sections.title: 5. Inversion (i)
sections.content:
Projection through the center of the molecule to the opposite side. This is mathematically equivalent to an $S_2$ improper rotation.

Example: **SF6** and **Staggered Ethane** have centers of inversion.

visuals.note: Sulfur Hexafluoride (Oh) has a center of inversion.

sections.title: 6. Point Groups & Flowchart
sections.content:
We classify molecules into **Point Groups** based on their complete set of symmetry elements.
- **Low Symmetry:** C1, Cs, Ci
- **High Symmetry:** Td, Oh, Ih
- **D Groups:** Have $n$ $C_2$ axes perpendicular to principal $C_n$.
